Title.evidence: Long-term Impact of Mesh Type on Chronic Pain in Open Anterior Inguinal Hernia Repair: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Participants.evidence: men aged 25 years or older with symptomatic unilateral inguinal hernia

Intervention.evidence: randomised (1:1) to receive either heavyweight (90 g/m²) or lightweight (28 g/m²) mesh

Objective.evidence: evaluated the long-term impact of heavyweight versus lightweight mesh on chronic pain

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was chronic pain affecting daily activities, measured by the Short-Form Inguinal Pain Questionnaire 9–12 years post-surgery

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed via a web-based server

Number_Analysed.evidence: 363 were analysed, with 271 completing the follow-up

Result_Outcome.evidence: Pain affecting daily activities was significantly less in the lightweight group (generalized odds 1.33, 95% CI 1.10 to 1.61; p = 0.004)

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported

Funding.evidence: The study was funded by Umeå University
